items.title: Federal Reserve holds interest rates steady amid Trump pressure

featured_image.name: Trump wants lower borrowing costs—but a Fed rate cut may be months away

items.description: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday announced it will leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 3.5%-3.75%, marking a pause after three consecutive quarter-point cuts late last year. The widely anticipated decision comes as Chair Jerome Powell navigates unprecedented political pressure from President Donald Trump and a Justice Department investigation that Powell has called a "pretext" for influencing monetary policy.

items.title: Fast-growing trees threaten forest diversity worldwide, study finds

featured_image.name: Diverse forests are stronger against drought | Stanford ...

items.description:
The world's forests are undergoing a transformation that may weaken their ecological integrity for decades to come. A comprehensive international study published January 27 in Nature Plants warns that fast-growing tree species are increasingly dominating forest ecosystems worldwide, displacing slower-growing native trees and reducing both biodiversity and long-term carbon storage capacity.[1][2][3]

The research team analyzed more than 31,000 tree species globally and found that forests are becoming homogenized as fast-growing varieties such as acacia, eucalyptus, poplar, and pine outcompete specialized native species. Nearly 41 percent of naturalized tree species—those that have established wild populations outside their native ranges—possess traits like rapid growth and small leaves that make them well-suited to disturbed environments but unable to fulfill the ecological roles of the species they replace.[2][4][1]

items.title: Bank of Canada holds rates steady, warns Fed independence threats add to global instability

featured_image.name: Threat to Fed's independence boosts economic uncertainty, says ...

items.description: The Bank of Canada on Wednesday maintained its benchmark interest rate at 2.25 percent, while the U.S. Federal Reserve is widely expected to keep its policy rate unchanged in the 3.5-3.75 percent range when it announces its decision later today. Both central banks are navigating elevated uncertainty, with Governor Tiff Macklem warning that threats to the Fed's independence add to global economic instability.[1][2][3]

items.title: Leaked draft shows Trump's Gaza board would grant him sweeping power

featured_image.name: What we know about Trump's Gaza plan

items.description:
A leaked document has revealed that President Donald Trump's newly established Board of Peace would grant him extraordinary authority over Gaza's governance, reconstruction, and legal framework, drawing sharp criticism from humanitarian leaders and sparking divisions among U.S. allies.

The unsigned draft resolution, dated January 22 and obtained by Drop Site News from three independent sources, shows that Trump would serve as chairman with power to sign all resolutions into force, approve military commanders, and appoint key officials throughout the governing apparatus. The document states the Board would hold "all transitional legislative and executive authority, emergency powers, and the administration of justice" over Gaza.[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump warns Iran 'time is running out' as US naval fleet approaches

featured_image.name: US-Iran latest: Trump says 'massive armada' heading to Iran - and warns 'time is running out'

items.description:
President Donald Trump issued an urgent ultimatum to Iran on Wednesday, warning that "time is running out" to negotiate a nuclear agreement as a massive US naval fleet approaches the region. The warning escalates tensions weeks after deadly protests rocked Iran and following last year's US strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.

"Hopefully Iran will quickly 'come to the table' and negotiate a fair and equitable deal — NO NUCLEAR WEAPONS — one that is good for all parties," Trump wrote in a social media post, according to Reuters. "Time is running out, it is truly of the essence!"[1][2]

Trump explicitly referenced the previous US military strikes on Iran, warning that "the next attack will be far worse" if Tehran does not comply. The president also noted that a "huge armada is making its way to Iran with great speed and power" and would "fulfill its mission with speed and violence if necessary".[3][4][5][6]

items.title: China's solar and wind capacity surpasses coal for first time

featured_image.name: China has already reached 2030 renewable energy targets

items.description:
China installed a record 315 gigawatts of new solar capacity in 2025 alongside 119 gigawatts of wind power, pushing combined wind and solar capacity past coal-based thermal generation for the first time in the nation's history, according to official data released by the National Energy Administration on January 28.[1][2][3]

The figures mark a structural shift in the energy mix of the world's largest greenhouse gas emitter. By the end of December, China's cumulative wind and solar capacity reached 1.84 terawatts, exceeding thermal power by 300 million kilowatts and accounting for 47.3 percent of the country's total installed power generation capacity.[2][1]

items.title: Musk eyes June planetary alignment for record SpaceX IPO

featured_image.name: Musk Considers Timing SpaceX IPO With Planetary Alignment, FT Reports

items.description:
Elon Musk has proposed timing SpaceX's potential initial public offering to coincide with a rare planetary alignment in mid-June, according to the Financial Times. The rocket maker is targeting a $1.5 trillion valuation and aims to raise up to $50 billion, which would make it the largest IPO in history.[1][2][3][4][5]

The company is eyeing mid-June when Jupiter and Venus will appear very close together in the sky for the first time in more than three years, five people familiar with the matter told the Financial Times. On June 8 and 9, the two planets will be positioned within roughly 1.6 degrees of each other, about the width of a thumb held at arm's length, according to the nonprofit Planetary Society. Musk's 55th birthday on June 28 was also a factor in the timing decision, sources said.[2][3][6][5][7][8][1]

items.title: Dollar recovers from four-year low as traders await Fed decision

featured_image.name: Dollar's 'Relentless' Slide Has Traders Bracing for More Pain

items.description:
The U.S. dollar clawed back some ground on Wednesday after tumbling to a four-year low, as markets turned their attention to the Federal Reserve's first policy decision of 2026.

President Donald Trump's casual dismissal of the currency's recent slide triggered the sharpest single-day drop in the greenback since the tariff upheaval in April. When asked Tuesday whether the dollar had declined too much, Trump told reporters in Iowa, "No, I think it's great," adding that it should "just seek its own level." Traders interpreted the remarks as a green light to sell the U.S. currency aggressively.[1][2][3]

items.title: European stocks slip as investors await Fed rate decision

featured_image.name: European shares pause after two-day rally; ASML bucks weakness

items.description:
European stock markets traded lower on Wednesday as investors exercised caution ahead of the Federal Reserve's first interest rate decision of 2026, while contrasting corporate earnings results created a mixed sector backdrop.

The CAC 40 in Paris dropped about 0.9% to around 8,080 points at midday, weighed down heavily by disappointing results from luxury giant LVMH. The FTSE 100 in London fell 0.4% to 10,165.25, while the DAX in Frankfurt slipped 0.2%. The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index declined 0.4%.[1][2][3]

items.title: Over 50 million in West Africa face acute hunger by summer, UN warns

featured_image.name: Floods hit millions in West and Central Africa

items.description:
A worsening pattern of climate-driven displacement and hunger is taking shape across the globe, as rising sea levels threaten coastal communities from Liberia to Hawaii while crop losses deepen food insecurity affecting tens of millions in Africa.

The United Nations World Food Programme warned in January that 318 million people now face crisis levels of hunger or worse globally—more than double the figure recorded in 2019. In West Africa and the Sahel alone, the Food and Agriculture Organization reported this week that 41.8 million people are currently experiencing acute food insecurity, a number projected to climb to 52.8 million during the June-August lean season without urgent intervention.[1][2][3]

items.title: Gold hits record high above $5,300 as dollar tumbles

featured_image.name: Gold goes past $5,200 as dollar plummets

items.description:
Gold prices breached the $5,300 mark for the first time on Wednesday, hitting an all-time high of $5,311.31 per ounce as the U.S. dollar plunged to a near four-year low ahead of the Federal Reserve's first interest rate decision of 2026.[1][2][3]

The precious metal climbed as much as 2.3% during the session, extending a blistering rally that has seen prices surge more than 20% since the start of the year. The gains followed a 3.4% jump on Tuesday, the largest single-day increase since April.[4][1]

items.title: Webb telescope may have found birthplaces of massive black holes

featured_image.name: Princeton astrophysicist helps find record-smashing black ...

items.description:
A growing body of research suggests that mysterious objects called "Little Red Dots," discovered by the James Webb Space Telescope, may represent the first observational evidence of direct-collapse black holes forming in the early universe—potentially solving one of astronomy's most vexing puzzles.

These compact, red objects, identified through deep extragalactic surveys conducted by the JWST since it began operations in 2022, existed when the universe was less than a billion years old. Scientists now believe they could be witnessing the birth of the most massive black holes in the cosmos.

items.title: EU to elevate Vietnam ties to highest level during Costa visit

featured_image.name: EU hopes to lift ties with Viet Nam into comprehensive ...

items.description:
The European Union and Vietnam are set to deepen cooperation on critical minerals, semiconductors, and "trusted" 5G communications infrastructure during European Council President António Costa's visit to Hanoi this week, according to a draft joint statement reviewed by Reuters.[1][2][3]

The eight-page document, scheduled to be adopted on Thursday when Costa meets Vietnamese leaders, will elevate diplomatic ties to Vietnam's highest level—placing the EU on the same tier as the United States, China, and Russia.[2][1]

items.title: Indonesian stocks plunge after MSCI freezes index additions

featured_image.name: Indonesia's stock market suspended for 30 minutes after ...

items.description:
Asian markets diverged sharply on Wednesday as investors weighed a fresh record on Wall Street and record-high gold prices against significant regional headwinds, including a plunge in Indonesian stocks and a weakening U.S. dollar ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

The S&P 500 closed at a record high on Tuesday, climbing 0.41% to 6,978.60 — its fourth record close of 2026 and fifth consecutive day of gains. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite also advanced, rising 0.91%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, however, fell amid pressure on health insurer stocks.[1][2][3]

items.title: Japanese researchers train AI to 'mumble' to itself

featured_image.name: Researchers find algorithm for large-scale brain simulations

items.description:
New research from Japan suggests artificial intelligence systems may benefit from a surprisingly human trait: talking to themselves. Scientists at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST) have demonstrated that AI models learn more efficiently, adapt to new situations more easily, and handle multiple tasks better when trained to use internal "mumbling" alongside short-term memory systems.

The findings, published in Neural Computation on January 28, reveal that combining self-directed inner speech with working memory architecture allows AI to generalize across different tasks more effectively while requiring far less training data than conventional approaches.[1][2]

items.title: South Korea's Kospi breaks 5,100 for first time as gold tops $5,200

featured_image.name: KOSPI tops 5,100 for the first time on record, KOSDAQ ...

items.description:
Asian markets delivered a mixed performance on Wednesday as investors navigated a complex landscape of record-breaking U.S. equities, soaring precious metals, and a weakening dollar, all while awaiting the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision later in the day.

South Korea's Kospi broke through the 5,100 level for the first time in history, rising more than 1.5% in early trading. Meanwhile, Japan's Nikkei 225 fell about 0.5% as a strengthening yen weighed on export-heavy stocks. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index pointed to gains, with futures trading above the previous close.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: Gold hits record high as dollar falls to four-year low

featured_image.name: Trump triggers flight from US dollar

items.description:
The U.S. dollar tumbled to its lowest level since early 2022 on Tuesday after President Donald Trump appeared unconcerned about its recent slide, describing the currency as "doing great" when asked if it had fallen too much. The remarks accelerated a sell-off that lifted gold to record highs above $5,200 an ounce on Wednesday.

The dollar index, which measures the greenback against six major currencies, dropped to 95.566 on Tuesday — its weakest reading in nearly four years — before stabilizing around 96 in Asian trading on Wednesday. Trump's comments in Iowa intensified what had already been the currency's largest three-day drop since last April's tariff turmoil.[1][2][3]

items.title: Stone tools found in China push back date of composite technology in East Asia

featured_image.name: Oldest hafted stone tools in East Asia discovered in China ...

items.description:
Archaeologists working at the Xigou site in central China have unearthed more than 2,600 stone artifacts that represent the earliest known composite tools in East Asia, challenging the long-held assumption that early humans in the region lagged behind their African and European counterparts in technological innovation.

The findings, published this week in Nature Communications, document sophisticated toolmaking techniques spanning roughly 90,000 years at the site in Henan Province's Danjiangkou Reservoir Region.[1][2][3]

items.title: China approves first Nvidia H200 AI chip imports amid Huang visit

featured_image.name: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang in Shanghai amid China regulatory ...

items.description:
China has granted approval for its first shipment of Nvidia H200 artificial intelligence chips, marking a pivotal shift in Beijing's approach to balancing its AI ambitions with efforts to promote domestic semiconductor development. The authorization covers several hundred thousand units and was issued during Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang's ongoing visit to the country, according to Reuters.[1]

The approval, which extends to three major Chinese internet companies, signals a thaw in tensions that saw Chinese customs briefly block H200 shipments earlier this month despite U.S. export clearance. Sources indicate that Alibaba, Tencent, and ByteDance are among the firms granted initial clearance, with additional companies awaiting future approvals.[2][1]

items.title: AI could propose and test scientific hypotheses within five years, researchers say

featured_image.name: AI-led robotic lab develops enzyme to withstand higher ...

items.description:
Artificial intelligence could be autonomously generating scientific hypotheses and conducting research experiments within the next five years, according to leading researchers, even as philosophers and scientists debate whether machines can ever truly replace human researchers.

EPFL associate professor Robert West and Northwestern University professor Ágnes Horvát said in an interview published this week that the role of AI in science is poised for a fundamental shift—from assisting with writing and data analysis to actually proposing the questions that drive research.[1][2]

"I think the next step, and perhaps five years is a reasonable time frame for that, is for AI to come up with the ideas we study," Horvát said. "That's very different territory because then the AI is providing the hypothesis that needs to be researched."[1]
